newsitem.title: USA: Kaczynski pleads not guilty on New Jersey charge.
newsitem.headline: Kaczynski pleads not guilty on New Jersey charge.

text.p: Accused "Unabomber" Theodore Kaczynski pleaded not guilty to a murder charge on Tuesday by video teleconference, but a judge reserved a decision on whether to try him in New Jersey before a separate trial in California.
U.S. District Judge Dickinson Debevoise of Newark federal court said he would rule in a week on Kaczynski, who faces federal murder charges in two states for a bombing spree that began in the 1970s.

In the video conference from Sacramento, Kaczynski, wearing a white shirt and a brown jacket without a tie, looked calm and answered "Yes, I do" when the judge asked him whether he waived his right to a trial on the New Jersey indictment.
Prosecutors in New Jersey want a separate trial in the state to begin in June. His California trial is scheduled to start on Nov. 12 in Sacramento, where he is being held without bail.
He faces charges in New Jersey in the 1984 death of an advertising executive killed by a parcel bomb mailed to his home. Authorities alleged that Kaczynski mailed the bomb from San Francisco.
Kaczynski's attorneys have argued that the charges be consolidated into one case in California, where Kaczynski is accused of four bomb attacks that killed two people and injured two others.
The judge said that if he decides to hold a trial in New Jersey, then it would not start until after the end of the California trial.
"That would create too much confusion to have a trial here that may overlap with a trial in Sacramento," Judge Debevoise said.
Kaczynski, a former mathematics professor who became a recluse, was arrested in April at his one-room cabin in rural Montana.
